review_title: A culture of bigotry, racism, greed, and gossip.
pros: None. Avoid at all costs.
cons:
The entire culture of Troy is the pushing of racist mindsets on the other professors. It’s not uncommon for another professor or administrator to hurl racist or bigoted comments about their students or current culture. The university does not punish faculty for giving alcohol to students, asking students to pose sexually in photos, or continually gossip about students, teachers, or admin.

Faculty will refer to black students with the N-word. I’ve heard admin refer to the black students as a financial burden on society and the university. A department chair referred to the Chinese students with racist impersonations. If you’re not white on this campus then you’re a target for discrimination. Most of the Black/African American students keep their heads down because they’re scared the faculty will fail them just because they can. They (faculty) will mistreat these students constantly.

It is a sick and disgusting military influenced work culture. They (admin) don’t help and only pile more and more responsibilities on to the faculty leading to the faculty constantly being over worked and under paid. When there are cutbacks the admin pulls classes and funds from faculty to make their profit. They say this school is non profit but their sole goal is to continually make money and move it around to hide it.

The faculty are severely underpaid and understaffed in some departments. The admin and deans hoard funds for their departments while letting other departments languish. For example, a dean is also the department chair and will funnel funds to his department over other departments. This keeps other areas from ever getting accreditation. This same dean will take student funds from all of the departments they oversee to fund events or buy equipment for their department.

Faulty are told to keep their mouths shut and their opinions to themselves. I’ve seen several faculty fired in my time at Troy for their support of student groups or for blowing the whistle on the work culture. Faculty art told they can't support the atheist organization.

The university forces faculty into prayer at work events violating the rights of its staff. They’ll make non Christians pray to their god during work training and announcements. You will be reprimanded if you do not bow your head at the yearly address or at graduation.

Their Covid response was horrible. They lost so much money in the spring of 2020 that they forced students and teachers back on campus without any safety precautions in place. Faculty were expected to maintain the same classroom environment regardless of safety. Many students and staff were exposed to Covid and the administration stayed at home working remotely. I was told point blank that the only reason we’re back on campus is to get money from the students and that safety isn’t their concern. The university took government money to buy safety equipment and never distributed it. Thermometers we’re purchased but never given to faculty or staff because we were told it would require two weeks of training to check temperatures. No contract tracing took place. There was no consistency to sanitize communal spaces.

Troy also increased its online classes tuition during the pandemic.

I would avoid Troy university at all costs.

review_title: Most disorganized institution I have ever worked for.
pros: Flexible schedule, overall nice co-workers and relatively easy work.
cons: When you are a new employee there is no training, no handbook, no guidelines, no standards, no rules... nothing.  I have never dealt with a University that had so little to offer with regard to structure and organization.  The courses seem to be haphazardly put together with no real thought behind it.  It is a degree mill, unfortunately.  It does not seem that the students are truly worth more than the money they spend to the institution.  For an adjunct position, it is so much more work than the compensation if you actually want to be a good instructor and care about your students.  Onboarding was a nightmare with no orientation, information on how things work at this University, etc.  Nothing.  If I didn't constantly ask questions, I wouldn't have had my tax paperwork, ID card, parking pass, etc.  I have had to be the person to manage and navigate being an employee there with little guidance, just really good guessing.  No employee, certainly not one being paid so little, should have to do that.  It was like feeling around in the dark since day one.

pros: The work was great, I loved the coworkers and students that were there.
cons: I was hired for specific days and hours and promised that I would be given only those hours.  I went over extra and said I would work one Saturday for them because they needed the help that day.  I was then put on the weekly schedule for that day, even thought I didn't volunteer or ask for that.  The head Chief was angered that I would not be able to work every week from then on for that one time request of my time and shortened my hours to 3 hrs a week. and 1 day a week.  I could not get any satisfaction from the person that hired me for this act, so I resigned.

review_title: DONT RECRUIT FOR TROY!!! UNLESS YOUR DADDY HAS PULL
pros:
-You can earn your next level degree for free if you stay long enough
-A chance to route for a spirited team, Go Trojans
-A stepping stone and resume builder for a better University job elsewhere.
cons:
-Beware the favoritism that will be shown to anybody with a Troy undergraduate degree
-It was a personal playground for the "darlings"of Troy
-The slightest incident and they will build a case against you to force you out
- This was the most unorganized company I've ever worked 
- You have to know somebody to get promoted
- You will not have a voice so don't speak up in meetings or voice any of your opinions
- Old and out of touch people run the show and you will feel light years behind the competing schools you go up against
- Only work here if you need flexible hours to plan for your future
-Ask for a raise and it will be the death of you
-They build value in titles not people. You will not rise through the ranks unless you the right people love you
-Work for the Southeast region or for any of there so-called leaders and you will regret it

review_title: My experience with Troy University eCampus/eTROY/TROY Global Campus has been terrible.
pros: If you work in the right area, you get two weeks off for Christmas break; however, they threaten to take it away (among other things) all the time.
cons: Upper management is only worried about what they are going to eat for lunch.  They have no knowledge or desire to gain knowledge of the University and its policies.  My supervisor sends two or three e-mails a day at times, but has never sent one about actual work duties.  They are mostly to call us immature and tell us that we are forbidden to speak with employees in other departments or the supervisor at the next level.

pros: steady paycheck and not overly compensated
cons: Enrollment declines because students are not happy, faculty are not happy, and staff works non-stop reinventing the wheel.   Disconnect between top management and the working force.  A culture of Us and Them . Admin needs to listen to the workers on the front lines who can offer "fixes" for problems. Over the past five years, the Admin is becoming more Troy-Centric and has lost the vision of a global reach.  A power play for CONTROL is evident on the Troy Campus....it is not an efficient way to operate. The morale of the workers is in the pits - the management doesn't care and that is what is so sad. The Admin doesn't want to know any BAD news so they continue to operate as Pollyanna.....very sad situation. Good people leave every month and no one ever asks why ....this institution is a train wreck.

pros: Time off during the holidays, tuition assistance and discount. Health Benefits. Depending in the area that you work for you can be appreciated and treated with respect. Working with young adults and see them flourish during their college career is very rewarding. Seeing first hand basis how caring the faculty are is an added bonus.
cons: Nepotism very prevalent through out the University. Pay is not equal based on education or experience but more on whether you are a family member and or liked by upper management. There are a lot of chiefs and not enough Indians. Very cut throat environment.

pros: This is an fairly easy job, you will find most of the time you just have to sit there.  If you are an CS grad student with a 3.0 or above you are most certainly can get the job.
cons: This job is very tedious and boring. you would have to figure out some way to kill time I guess. some student were very noisy, and exams are given in the lab form time to time It's your job to oversee the exams.

review_title: Be careful, Troy is only out for themselves
pros: I enjoyed working with my co-workers, the University offers many holiday days, for the most part it is easy to obtain and take vacation and sick leave.
cons: Troy does not provide adequate training for their supervisors, I had more than 1 supervisor who committed ethical violations and were caught harassing other employees.  There is a lack of communication within Troy.  Be aware that Troy's Deans will likely lie to you about their intentions and may lead you to believe that they care about the employees when in fact they do not.  Also, there is a lot of nepotism that is allowed to occur!

job_title: International Student Advisor in Troy, AL
pros: The people working at the school are great.
cons: You will be expected to work a lot of over time in this position without any kind of official compensation. Thankfully,  the person currently in charge is aware of this and allows a little extra time off in the slower periods. Also, the majority of the positions in our department are either considered entry-level or director-level with not much between, so I would view working at this school as a stepping stone that will lead to someplace better once you have a little experience.

pros: As a professor, you have a lot more freedom to pursue your own kind of research, without having to work for a subpar institution in exchange for that freedom.
cons: Your work-life balance depends heavily on your location. The Alabama campus locations are great, but if you work at one of the many sites around the world, you have to fight pretty hard to keep the administrative hierarchy from overloading you with work.

review_title: TROY univ in Atlanta - NOT the place to work
pros: to fend off starvation, they have this 'family' attitude, but it is FAR from it. There are certain persons that have never worked for another College and Univ, so they have NO idea that they are not  within the professional 'Norm'.
cons: management has NO idea that moral is so low that EVERYONE is looking for other jobs. ALSO the need to move into the information age is WAY overdue. The lack in technical skill is most apparent in the fact that the student computers are older than my 80 year old grandmothers!

job_title: Computer Support Technician in Troy, AL
pros: College atmosphere was great. Full cost of Tuition waved, time off, when the college is closed, you're off as well (except Spring break. The students had the whole week off, we just got Friday). It is essentially like working for the public sector (which it is) with the exception of more time off: 2 weeks for Christmas Holidays, 3 days for Thanksgiving, and the usual government holidays off: MLK, 4th, Labor Day, etc.
cons:
The city of Troy is very boring for a 28 year old. No night life, limited restaurants, entertainment non existent. Troy is great is you are raising a family, love the small town life, not looking for a lot to do on the weekends.  
I worked in I.T., the management was terrible. They certainly look down on you for asking for time off. One time our supervisor "got on to us" because we didn't look at out ticket queue over the Christmas Holidays (which we are not required to do being that our particular department was hourly). Everyone one is driven more by fear of being harassed by upper management than actually being personally motivated to get the job done. 

There are so many unrealistic expectations in the I.T. department at Troy. I never got a good positive vibe working there in the three years I was there. I remember when I put in my two weeks, the supervisors were upset that people kept taking the position that I was in and leaving within a year, the position only paid 24k. Their reason for being upset was that they said they were tired of the position being treated like a stepping stone. They were so disconnected from reality that they couldn't (or denied to) see the position for how it really was: a stepping stone position. But like I said, there were a lot of realistic expectations there.   

This is definitely one of the places where yelling takes place, arguments are heard out loud, and turnover in any position that is not upper management is rampant. 

Its sad too because I see how it could be a great place to work, but the people you have to work for here will need to retire or move on before the work atmosphere changes. I would strongly urge any one looking for a job here within I.T. to consider other options as long as the current CIO is there.

review_title: Departmental Secretary Job is for inexperienced beginners
pros: BCBS Health Insurance, Retirement Fund, 50% paid tuition after one year of employment available, sick leave and annual leave accrual, potential for advancement
cons: LOW PAY! Very little training is prepared for a new employee, takes weeks to get all your logins for computer use and the gossip between other secretaries is high.

pros: I have a great team working with me at the Troy University - Savannah Site and Troy University is a great school that is easy to promote.
cons: We have been given a tremendous challenge for enrollment numbers but lack sufficient leadership and guidance from the main campus along with insufficient marketing support and a "chain gang" mentality from the administration.

review_title: Loyal Company as long as you are Hard Working

cons: Share information more with the Global Campus Sites quickly rather than later. Also take into factor the amount of travel each site does when planning budgets.

Excellent local management and work-life balance, great coworkers, 
good benefits (health and education), enjoyed working with and assisting students. 
Troy is a quality and reputable school that I enjoyed working for but the leadership leaves a lot to be desired.

~poor communication and support between main campus and satellite locations
~poor management at the main campus level
~few opportunities for growth/promotion unless you want to move to Alabama

pros: none except you do get a paycheck
cons: not offered professional development opportunities to enhance my job performance - policies were never written only oral and changed when the wind blew - kind of like a company store - you owe your soul to TU and there is no work/life balance, just live to work!

pros: Perfect position for a student. Good environment for study beside work. Well decorated with different current technologies. Its a good place to work.
cons: Rather than university, It is hard to find anything here. If you are kind of fun loving people then it is not suited for you. If you want to work and study at a time , it is hard to find a job here.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Panama City, FL
pros: Great people. Reasonable quotas. Flexible work environment that did not require you to be in the office all the time. Pension eligibility if you stay long enough.
cons: Very limited room for upward mobility outside of main campus. Upper management extremely resistant to change or modern models of networking, especially social media. Lower than average salary.

pros: Technically gaining experience in desired field of student services/higher education
cons: Truly nothing positive to say - no direction, no real training, expect 24/7 commitment to Troy, but provide no reason to think Troy is anything more than second rate.  Management has no idea what they're doing or what they want - expect recruiters to magically bring in hundreds of 'quality' students with no regard for how to do it and reject every idea of how improvements could be made.  Feel stuck and desperate, and the management's attitude is that anyone should just be grateful to have a job.

review_title: Love the institution, but the workload is tough
pros: Public education benefits (insurance, retirement, etc.), college environment, make a difference in people's lives, and federal holidays. Campus is growing so you physically see the successes of the university
cons: Low pay, little room to move up until people retire, there's limited staff so there's a lot more work on the little guys

pros: Flexible schedule, a few hard working employees, and good benefits
cons: Overworked and underpaid.  Pay at Troy is much less than any other higher education institution with the same position.  Many employees come and go when they won’t and don’t work, which puts more on the good employees.  Leadership does nothing about misconduct of employees.

pros: Easy work, however management style is really badly managed. However, hours are really flexible to work around your schedule.
cons: Poor management. Need to create more of an environment where good people rise to the top. Need to treat some employees better especially in international department.

pros: Experience and ability to work with students.
cons: Poor supervision, no direction in supervision, lots of micromanagement. You have to be a student to have the job, however, management is unwilling to work around your schedule. Overall, poor treatment of lower level employees. Often times, management will ask you to do things that do not pertain to your job. High expectations of lower level employees and low expectations for management.

review_title: 10 years in the belly of  Troy.
job_title: Online Instructional Designer in Troy, AL
pros: Troy is actively trying to expand their all courses to an online environment.
cons:
Recent changes in management have changed the culture of Troy. Before, it used to be a pro-academic format, worrying about course content and providing the best courses available. Now it is more about quantity than quality.  With recent changes they have lost all but one qualified Instructional Designers. The one remaining is qualified only in a limited field, but that one is now handling over 200 courses. They remaining people filling the jobs do not have the required education, a Masters degree, nor are they in the process of getting it. They seem to feel that anyone can do the job and that employees are the least important resource available. They feel that they will be able to replace skilled employees with anyone at anytime. They use non-existent "secret" policies to bully employees and regularly threaten employees for taking vacation, taking sick days and using the Federally mandated Family Medical Leave Act. HR is simply a rubber stamp with no concern for employees. Their reputation is known throughout the state of Alabama..

This once was a good place to work, but no more. Less concern about having the job done right and more concern about quantity of "butts in the seats" both online and on-campus.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Troy, AL
pros: great working environment, team work as family, really nice campus and a lot of possibilities to move around.
cons: hiring freeze right now, salary and benefits are not that great but if you live in the area, it can be alright.

cons: Disparity among staff members doing their fair share. Lack of basic computer skills in some was acceptable for their seemingly charming personality. Constant dissemination of incorrect information

pros: Coworkers and much of the faculty are wonderful.
